title: Sainsbury's hopeful on profits despite supermarket price war
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Sep 30, 2015, 08:54 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 36 mins Sainsbury's hopeful on profits despite supermarket price war By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 12 minutes ago 0.00 
The grocer says profits should be 'moderately' ahead of expectations, despite stiff competition and price deflation 
Sainsbury (Amsterdam: SJ6.AS - news ) 's expects full-year profits to be "moderately" ahead of City expectations after posting a 0.3pc lift in total sales for the second quarter. 
Like-for-like sales were down by 1.1pc during the 16 weeks to September 26, in line with analyst consensus. 
Sainsbury's, which has been engulfed in a supermarket price war, said that it was shying away from heavy promotions in favour of lowering prices for the long term. 
Grocers have been battling it out in what many believe to be the toughest trading environment on record as they face food deflation and the rapid expansion of low-cost German rivals Aldi and Lidl. 
“During the quarter we saw an improvement in our key trading metrics," said Mike Coupe, Sainsbury's chief executive. 
"Both volume and transactions grew as the decline in average basket spend in supermarkets continued to stabilise. Whilst the market is clearly still challenging, with food deflation impacting many categories, we are making good progress on delivering our strategy." 
Sainsbury's said that "should current market trends continue, we expect our full-year underlying profit before tax to be moderately ahead of our published consensus". 
The retailer opened 27 new convenience stores in the past 16 weeks, indicating that smaller stores are forming part of the new space race for supermarkets as they target shoppers who are shunning the weekly shop in favour of smaller and more frequent trips to stores. 
Grocery online orders grew by 15pc and the supermarket said that since the launch of its Tu clothing brand online six weeks ago trading had "significantly exceeded expectations". 
Sainsbury's clothing sales grew by nearly 13pc in the last quarter, buoyed by a 'back to school' campaign that saw it sell 640,000 pairs of boys' trousers. 
The grocer said that it had improved product availability and cut waste levels as a result of better demand forecasting. Sainsbury's is attempting to enhance the quality of over 3,000 own-branded products; it has improved the quality and ripeness of avocados, which have surged in popularity over the past 18 months thanks to a trend towards health-conscious cooking. 
Last week Sainsbury's was shown to be the only one of the "big four" supermarkets to grow sales for the 12 weeks to September 13 , according to figures from Kantar Worldpanel.
